body.p: To his Excellency Beriah Magoffin Governor of the Commonwealth of Kentucky:

Your petitioner James Ferguson, would respectfully represent to your Excellency that at the April Term 1859 of the Clinton Circuit Court two indictments were found against him for assault; and at the October Term 1859 of said court, Said indictments or causes were tried; and upon one, judgment was rendered against your petitioner, for one hundred and fifty dollars; and upon the other, judgment was entered for fifty dollars. and afterwards, viz: on the day of 1859, Benjamin Ferguson and A. T. Harper replevied Said fines for your petition in order to keep him out of prison. Your petitioner would further state to your Excellency that he is a peacable, quiet, and industrious man and that he is poor and has a family to support, and that if he is compelled to pay off Said fines that his family will suffer -- He further states or admits that he was guilty of the assaults charged, according to the representations made to him since for he states that he had become intoxicated with spirituous liquors and knew not what he did do upon that occasion -- He further states that nobody was hurt nor touched upon the occasion, that the greatest offense committed by your petition was considerable loud talk and gesticulations which was
considered as amounting to an assault, that he has been upon perfectly friendly terms with the persons said to have been assaulted, ever since, and there would have been nothing of it except for spiritous liquors drank by your petitioner and he regrets the matter as much as anybody -- he sincerely regrets it and it is not often that he does become intoxicated and never was so before or since, that he did not know what he was doing. He states that when sober he attends to his own business and does not get into dificulties with his fellow citizens As he got into the dificulty accidentily and thinks the fines excessive, and as it pains him to see his hard earned property draged from his wife and little children he has ^con^cluded to ask the interposition of your Excellencys clemency and ^petition^ ask you to remit Said fines and release his said Securities from their security ship and promising to profit by the lesson taught him and to avoid such dificulties in the future --

To his Excellency Beriah Magoffin Governor of the Commonwealth of Kentucky: Your petitioners would respectfully state to your Excellency that they have read or heard read the Statements made in the foregoing petition of James Ferguson and that the same are true and that his case is one that deserves Executive clemency We therefore petition your Excelly to interpose and remit said fines -- We would further represent that the crops in this section were cut very short by the drouth and that money matters are very stringent and that it is all a poor man can do to support his family in the present crisis --

G W Braswell
